articles.headline: Justices Rule for Protesters at Military Funerals
articles.snippet: The First Amendment protects hateful protests at military funerals, the Supreme Court ruled in an 8-to-1 decision.
articles.abstract: The First Amendment protects hateful protests at military funerals, the Supreme Court ruled in an 8-to-1 decision.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  The First Amendment protects hateful protests at military funerals, the Supreme Court ruled on Wednesday in an 8-to-1 decision.

articles.headline: Jobs Returns to Introduce a New iPad
articles.snippet: Apple’s chief executive interrupted a medical leave to introduce the much-anticipated new tablet.
articles.abstract: Apple’s chief executive interrupted a medical leave to introduce the much-anticipated new tablet.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO  Steven P. Jobs, Apple’s chief executive, interrupted his medical leave on Wednesday to introduce the company’s much-anticipated new iPad, a thinner, faster and lighter version of its popular tablet computer that will sell at the same prices as the original models.

articles.headline: Cable TV in Pursuit of Mobility
articles.snippet: Comcast may be the nation’s biggest cable company, but it still faces tough competition from the Internet.
articles.abstract: Comcast may be the nation’s biggest cable company, but it still faces tough competition from the Internet.
articles.lead_paragraph: FOR INTERNAL COMCAST USE ONLY. DO NOT LEAK.

articles.headline: Staying in Touch With Technology
articles.snippet: New technologies are most commonly encountered through co-workers or as part of a corporate system, but retiring doesn’t have to mean falling out of touch.
articles.abstract: New technologies are most commonly encountered through co-workers or as part of a corporate system, but retiring doesn’t have to mean falling out of touch.
articles.lead_paragraph: HERE is the problem with typical “elder tech” products: there’s not enough “tech” in a phone that uses an oversize keypad but offers limited features, for one example. Advancing age can rob people of their abilities, and products that help mitigate that are good things indeed. But what if the need for that kind of assistance is still decades away? Today’s baby boomers are just now crossing the retirement line, but that does not render them incapacitated. Far from it. It may, however, render them out of touch.

articles.headline: Making the Most Out of Less
articles.snippet: For baby boomers and beyond, a comfortable retirement will be more difficult to achieve.
articles.abstract: For baby boomers and beyond, a comfortable retirement will be more difficult to achieve.
articles.lead_paragraph: JEFF NELSON, a manager in the Utah Health Department, says he constantly scolds himself for not setting aside more for retirement. “It’s always there, like that squeaky screen door in back that you want to fix , but you never get to,” said Mr. Nelson, 40, the father of a 10-year-old and 7 -year-old. “I feel I have more pressing needs. I have to make the house payment. I have to make the car payment.”

articles.headline: Wife’s Charity Offers Corporate Tie to a Governor
articles.snippet: Corporations are restricted in making contributions to Gov. Bobby Jindal of Louisiana. But they can give whatever they like to the foundation set up by his wife.
articles.abstract: Corporations are restricted in making contributions to Gov. Bobby Jindal of Louisiana. But they can give whatever they like to the foundation set up by his wife.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Louisiana’s biggest corporate players, many with long agendas before the state government, are restricted in making campaign contributions to Gov. Bobby Jindal. But they can give whatever they like to the foundation set up by his wife months after he took office.

articles.headline: Officials Disagree on Penalties for Mortgage Mess
articles.snippet: Regulators cannot agree on how much to punish banks as well as exactly who should benefit from a settlement.
articles.abstract: Regulators cannot agree on how much to punish banks as well as exactly who should benefit from a settlement.
articles.lead_paragraph: Even as state attorneys general and regulators in Washington approach the end of their investigation into abuses by the nation’s biggest mortgage companies, deep disputes are emerging over how much to punish the banks as well as exactly who should benefit from a settlement.
articles.byline: By Nelson D. Schwartz and David Streitfeld

articles.headline: Terror Quiets Libyan Capital as Rebels Battle in the East
articles.snippet: Tripoli residents say they are living in fear, while rebels celebrated a victory over Qaddafi’s forces in a strategic oil town.
articles.abstract: Tripoli residents say they are living in fear, while rebels celebrated a victory over Qaddafi’s forces in a strategic oil town.
articles.lead_paragraph: TRIPOLI, Libya  A state of terror has seized two working-class neighborhoods here that just a week ago exploded in revolt, with residents reporting constant surveillance, searches of cars and even cellphones by militiamen with Kalashnikovs at block-by-block checkpoints and a rash of disappearances of those involved in last week’s protest.

articles.headline: Pressure Limits Efforts to Police Drilling for Gas
articles.snippet: Amid pressure, regulators are divided over the scope of their powers, leading to limited enforcement and narrowed research.
articles.abstract: Amid pressure, regulators are divided over the scope of their powers, leading to limited enforcement and narrowed research.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Congress considered whether to regulate more closely the handling of wastes from oil and gas drilling in the 1980s, it turned to the Environmental Protection Agency to research the matter. E.P.A. researchers concluded that some of the drillers’ waste was hazardous and should be tightly controlled.
